title: Just started investing. Should I put money into China?
description: I know people have been saying stay out of china, but I see some companies like Sina Corp are actually doing well, would it be ok to go into those companies?

answers.comment: Remember that the Chinese market is still up over 60% this year. The government continues to make policies that are keeping the market artificially high. Chinese growth is expected to slow significantly over the coming years. Investing in China at this point is an extremely risky place to be. Wouldn't recommend taking on a lot of exposure at this point. Buying China is like buying a lottery ticket right now.
I feel around this time would be safe to pick up a few Chinese stocks. Diversity is usually good. However, if you still want to eat tomorrow, I'd be careful where you place your bets.

I have a question for someone in this thread. I thought you have to be a Chinese citizen to buy Chinese stocks? Like, when I opened my vanguard account, you have to be a US citizen? Can an American even purchase Chinese stocks?

I was looking at HOLI which sells on the nasdaq and seems to have great financials. Also, there's always the option of going for an emerging market ETF that has big portion of the portfolio dedicated to stocks in china. (XEC.TO)
The SEC doesn't operate in China. I see no reason to trust numbers Chinese companies put out for their financials.
Only if you want to hop along for Mr. Toad's wild ride. Also, the Chinese don't share the American/Western commitment to, uh, honest accounting practices.
But I mean like, if I wanted to by the actual chinese stocks that a chinese citizen buys, that wouldn't be possible right?
I'd recommend buying on the HK market. Although the volatility is lacking at least you can withdraw your winnings.

title: Why are so many people boycotting Nestle

answers.comment:
Because they have some pretty evil business practices in 3rd world countries, especially in Africa. 
In Africa, they have a program to give free (at first) baby food to mothers who can't afford to buy it. Then, after the mothers stop producing milk naturally from their breasts, Nestlé stops providing it for free and charges ridiculous prices for the baby food. Since their breasts no longer produce milk, the mothers are forced to pay for the food if they want their child to live.

1: They use slave labor to make their chocolate 
2: They buy water rights from drought stricken areas to bottle up and sell 
3: They make noodles with extremely high lead content, which can lead to health problems
Lol I actually never knew they had such a big amount of products… I thought they just did chocolate!
